"Wait, I'm already inside her." - Protagonist. 
Fate/stay night sure is a peculiar show. If I had to describe it in one paragraph, I'd say it's a fantasy & shounen based anime with mythological & religious undertones and what looks like a... good lawd, the tamest romantic component ever to be seen. It also contains numerous eye-brow raising one liners, cringeworthy German and badass fighting scenes. And somehow all this combines to make a decent show. 
Let's get to the meat and potatoes. (NOTE: this review is based only on the anime)
Fate/stay night follows the daily life of Emiya Shirou, a 17 year old boywho through hard work and determination exudes a powerful aura of testosterone that attracts his purple headed classmate (Sakura Matou) to make him breakfast and accompany him every single morning. Joining them is Taiga, his naggy and clingy guardian. His days pass blissfully in the company of fine women until the universe decides it has had enough of Emiya's shit and decides to fuck his life up by proclaiming a free for all death match called 'The Holy Grail War' and allowing a bunch of nerds to summon 7  warriors that will serve them and fight for the possession of the Holy Grail, an item said to grant its holder any wish. The heroes summoned are composed of a female knight that shouts every time she swings a sword (Sabre, who will also be Emiya's servant), an archer that doesn't carry a bow (Archer), a pink headed stripper ("Rider"), Schwarzenegger's arc-nemesis (Berserker), LeBlanc (Caster), a mellow long haired swordsman (Assassin)... and some guy called Lancer. A most wondrous of casts, wouldn't you agree?


Fate/stay night largely stays on point when it comes to story and character progression. I can only recall a single fillerish episode but even that one turned out to be plot significant in a way. That's one of the things that I really liked about this show and it's a quality that's not easy to find in Shounen anime. You can also see clear character progression and how that progression affects the links between the members of the cast. An example of this would be Emiya strapping on a major pair of balls and actively supporting his armour-clad sista from another mista instead of squirming away from fights and making her pissed off all the time. 



Also it's important to note that this show loves to flex its martial biceps and display only the best of fights for its audience. That's right. No bullshit, no orifices barred, all in Michael Bay style fighting scenes. It's stay/fate night's strong point. The show however tends to get a little too melodramatic and carried away. Be prepared for constant flashbacks and larger-than-life philosophical narratives even during the tiniest of scuffles. It does get a little tedious at times and you wish they'd shut the fuck up and just fight instead of discussing their secret tactics for god knows how long (lol Bleach anyone?). But all in all, the plot will still draw you in, the fights are good and the protagonist is cheesier than an obese skater performing 360s in nothing but aqua coloured latex pants. All as it should be. 


The art style and quality is very good even when compared to more recent releases. The animation is fluid all throughout and fights aesthetically pleasing. The voice acting is likewise good, especially all the growls and battle cries. The OST and opening isn't bad but not that special either. I just considered it meh for the entire duration of the series. 


Again, the enjoyment section is a very strong point of Fate/stay night. The story is intriguing and interesting, especially that mythological aspect though I can't say exactly what it is to avoid spoiling things. The only lacklustre aspect here is that the romance (which I haven't touched upon at all and for good reason) is extremely tame and slow and I shit you not, it'll take practically the length of the entire series before you'll see any semblance of a classical romance. But then again, it's like expecting romance in DBZ. 


8 points overall and I'd generally recommend this to anyone.


Thanks for reading and let me leave you to ponder the meaning of this philosophical statement :


"People die when they are killed."

I just finished that anime after 2 days and I have to admit I'm fascinated, it rightfuly won a place between my favourite 5 animes on this web site. Let me explain all the parts now then =)
*My apologies, might contain spoilers*
Story 10/10 =
The story of this anime is truly amazing when you look at it from the eyes of main protagonist. You survive a horrible tragedy by a man you never knew, you get killed and revived by a girl that should be your rival, you summon a knight full of pride and learn just what the hell is going on. You're assumed byall others to be naive, your ideology about the main event is completly different to others. Even through all this, the main hero struggles till he loses his consciousness, even falls for his own servant. The ending of story touched me greatly, I just wish there was a sequel.


Art 10/10 = The design in anime is of a great quality, fighting effects and all surroundings aren't cheaply drawn. For those who like animes with nice quality, this anime is a good chocie.


Sound 10/10 = I find the music used really suitable for the anime's story and events in it. I do not know about others, but there were moments when my emotions just spread even more with music playing to a specific moment, be it romantic or of bravery in fight.


Character 10/10 = You really see all the characters, that the story goes with, to grow with each episode. Believes change, they realise a lot and all to the better. 

All characters there have their unique past and we learn a bit of it as the episode goes, always quite amazing the point of view about the characters.


Enjoyment 10/10 = If you've got enough free time to watch an anime of 24 episodes, I really recommend to watch this. Though, I'd like to point out that this anime won't be really suitable for people who prefer the "flawless" happy endings. In my case, I felt like crying , filled with emotions, at the end of the anime. Otherwise, this anime has many comedic situations and light atmosphere, but it also has these dramatic moments and high tension. Just like it goes in real life, one part of the day is light and all's right, then suddenly the day becomes "hell" or very dramatic/romantic, depending on what's going on.


Now, if you're going to watch the anime, have nice time watching it =)

I still hope there to be a sequel one day.

Surely someone might think giving it a 9 is overrating. But to be honest, taking a minute to admire what a masterpiece i have just finished, sure the animation itself might be lacking but justfying this by the fact that it was released in 2006, i dont think that any anime wouldve been better in terms of quality at that time. The most important thing, is the fact that i liked this route, the fate route more than the others, in terms of the romantic story between saber and shirou, this is easily the place where this anime shines, Oh i forgot to mention thatby far this anime has one of the best soundtracks ever.

The DEEN version of Fate/Stay Night is a funny case : when it came out in 2006, it was considered one of the best anime ever, but today, it gets a lot of hate.
So is it good? Is it bad?
STORY :
Fate/Stay Night is the first part of the Fate universe, one of the biggest phenomenon in Japan and certainly the most popular Visual Novel even today.
The story is about a battle between Mages, called the Holy Grail war. The reward : the all mighty Holy Grail, which is said to grant the wishes of the winner.
But Fate/Stay Night is also a basic Slice of Life: it's about the life of Emiya Shirou, a not-so-normal high-school boy as he was adopted and raised by a Mage after a tragedy that killed his parents and many other people.

Shirou gets dragged in the Holy Grail War when he witnesses a battle and unwillingly invokes a Servant (a "familiar" that must serve the Mage who invoke them during the war).

Basically, the show focus on the Holy Grail War and on the everyday life of the characters.

The story of the Holy Grail is absolutely awesome. Not only it makes for great fights, it also has a LOT of background, which is the barebone of a universe. The characters all have an interesting background... except they aren't all developed in this anime.

Why's that? Because the Fate universe has several "routes" (different scenario, that is), and this anime only focuses on the first one (simply called "Fate").

Each route focus on some characters, and forgets a bit of the others. Thus, by knowing only one route, you won't realize how deep some characters are.

Aside from that, the story has a lot of twists and revelations, which make it very interesting to follow, even though they talk a lot.


Then, there is the Slice of Life part. THAT is definitely the weak part of Fate/Stay Night, especially in this first route.

This is simply not interesting. They focus on basic school life and get too much into comedy, often forgetting this is about a deadly battle between Mages.

And there is this love story between the main characters (I'll come back on it later).


Long story short : the universe is awesome, the story of the Holy Grail is great, but it is indeed spoiled by a lot of Slice of Life. That said, this is mostly true for the first half of the show.

Then, in the second half, it gets really serious. Like, awesomely serious. You may here that a lot : the first half of this anime is boring, but the second half clearly make up for it with great battles, great revelations and twists.



ART :

Someone has to say it : DEEN studio has a really weird style. The light effects aren't realistic at all. The eyes are big and empty. If you enjoy the style, you may like it. Otherwise, you will be annoyed. Personnally, I really liked it.

Then, there is animation. Animation itself is... meh. But strangely, they do manage to make great fights. Archer vs Berserker is still one of the best anime fights ever.



SOUND :

Kawai Kenji is the compositor. A great name in the japanimation (he made music for Ghost in the Shell, Gundam 00, and many others).

I wouldn't say this is one of the best OSTs ever. But it does contain memorable themes, namely Emiya (which is a theme from the original VN, but with Kawai Kenji's style), Unmei no Yoru, Tenchi Hou Take.


CHARACTERS:

THIS is the strong hold of the Fate universe. THIS is why it is considered one of the best things ever.

Almost all the characters have an interesting background, some kind of involvement in the story, a mysterious side and/or a badass style.

Saber is one of the most badass anime women ever. Rin has a great temper. Emiya Kiritsugu, despite being dead before the series even begin, is awesome. Illya is the most evil little girl ever.


That said... in this anime, many characters actually aren't that great.

- Matou Sakura has a very tragic background, but it is not developed at all in this route (it is kept for another route).

- Emiya Shirô is an idealistic overpowered brat. He does have an interesting story, but his other versions in the other routes are way better.

- Kotomine Kirei seems quite cliché as a main villain. He is actually much more complex than that, but it is indeed better shown in Fate/Zero than in Fate/Stay Night.


Then, there is this stupid love story between Shirô and Saber. It simply does not work, as Saber is not in Shirô's league... and it is pointless to the main scenario.


Basically, if you want to enjoy the characters, you must understand that one route is not enough to know all of them. You have to watch all the routes and Fate/Zero, and only then, you'll have a hold on the complexity of each character.

But when it comes to this anime only, many characters are failed. Well, ther's still Saber, Rin, Archer, Gilgamesh. But the rest seems quite average, when they're actually great in other routes.



ENJOYMENT :

So, it seems there's a lot of problems in this anime. How come this be popular? Because most people know this is only ONE PART of an entire universe. It must not be taken alone.

DEEN's version of Fate/Stay Night is definitely the least good part of this universe. But it is also the first one. The Slice Of Life part is put away in the other routes (there's still some, but much, much less).

I really recommend watching this. Even if you don't like it in the end, it is the first stone of an entire universe, which you are sure to fairly enjoy.

That said, if you really don't want to watch all of the Fate anime adaptations, you can skip this and watch Fate/Stay Night (2014), then Fate/Zero, then Heaven's Feel (this route is made in 3 movies, that are currently being released in Japan).

Another computer game based anime. But it's very well done. The plot is thick, confusingly so at times. It can be quite complicated in parts and hard to follow but it is well worth the effort. I like that fact that the servants have a mythological basis even if it did become hard to remember who was who. I did watch it over a space of several months though so that could be a contributing factor to me finding it confusing and hard to follow. The animation was well done though, the character designs were great (especially thier backgrounds) and it was overall very prettyto watch. Good music too.


There was a good amount of action and fight scenes in  this anime. Not so much that it got boring yet enough that it kept you thinking 'oooooo'. There were bits of humour and fanservice, which is something I really value in shows that have a lot of action. It becomes a nice break and distraction, especially in anime that has a fairly serious tone. 


Despite the action and the humour I did find that this had sags in it's story line. Some times there would be lots going on and other times there would be hardly anything. That would be my main quibble about it, I wasn't at the edge of my seat the whole way through and thats something that I have come to expect and enjoy with good animes. 


Overall I very much enjoyed watching this. I found the Saber/Emiya 'ship to be cute and fun, the background to be interesting and the fight scenes to be cool. Everything that you need in a decent show. Thus I will happily reccomend it to anyone who likes a bit of action and fantasy. 


Nanashi Moriko *not a Fate/Stay Night fan girl but yet a fan*

21/01/08

At the time of writing this review, I have watched around 50 anime series and movies, and not once have I encountered one as appalling as Fate/Stay Night. Poor character development, atrocious characters, nonsense dialogue and predictable action sequences - this anime's got them all. The music and art were fine I suppose, but hardly anything remarkable - definitely something forgettable. The story was generic and predictable, therefore there isn't much to cover on that front.
First off, the character development. Well, it's nonexistent, so there's not much to talk about on this front either. All of the characters stay more or less the same asthe moment you meet them. 


The characters. Good God. The protagonist is a classic Mary Sue with plot armor thick as fog, with neither smart, nor brawn, but a lot of naivete. He's completely unlikable and forgettable. Oh, and he also happens to be pretty damn sexist - he forbids his servant(whose sole existence revolves around fighting for his sake) from taking up the sword because...she's a woman. The other characters are slightly less annoying, but just as one-dimensional. 


Nonsense dialogue. If you know the quote "People die when they're killed" - that's where its from. Yup. It's from Fate/Stay Night, and while since that phrase's glory days are long over and the translation has improved...there's still no meaning beneath the shallow dialogues, which goes from stating the obvious multiple times to constantly saying each other's names(seriously, I've heard the name "Saber" called out about 10 times in every single episode for no real reason). 


Well, I guess there was SOME amount of merit to be found in the action sequences. They were okay, if it was not for the fact that you knew precisely where things will pick up next as the scene unfolded before you. There were no surprises on that front. Something I found hilarious was the usage of random german words(as spells) and one of the characters suddenly monologuing in english for no real reason mid-fight(I suppose I didn't see that coming).


TL;DR Do not watch this. This is EXACTLY what people who say "Anime is trash" have in mind.

Fate/stay night (2006) is a prime example of the "great potential, poor execution" case where a manga, novel, game or, in this case, visual novel is adapted into an anime by a studio that was simply not up for the task.
But don't let this scare you. If you are able to ignore animation that best is pretty decent and at worst is pretty mediocre you will be able to enjoy a genuinely good anime that honestly gets too much hate from it's fanbase and the anime community in general. I also think it is the best place to start the Fate/Series
Story: Good (7.0/10)
The narrative istold through the perspective of Shirou Emiya and Saber as they fight in a 7-way battle royale style war for an object know as the Holy Grail while at the time both of them must face the dilemma of either fighting to fix the mistakes of the past and for the sake of others or live in the present and fight for yourself. I think the anime approached this question in a pretty interesting way even if it wasn't in the best way possible. The story is told in a slow pace but by being fairly engaging and interesting it is able to keep you decently invested throughout it's 24 episode run. 


Visuals: Average (5.0/10)

without a doubt this anime's biggest failing and the major reason why it is so heavily criticized and looked down upon by it's own fanbase.

Studio DEEN was able to successfully replicate the art style of the original visual novel in it's character designs and backgrounds but in terms of animation the show leaves much to be desired with clunky and stiff movements, (sometimes) badly drawn facial expressions and underwhelming visuals effects (which include an ugly CG Dragon) that most of the time lead to unintentional moments of laughter.

But one thing that surprised me was that in the last episode the visuals received a ridiculous upgrade in every aspect, with all the problems I mentioned above being corrected. But in my case it just made me question why they didn't do the whole show like that. If they had done the whole thing with as much quality as in the last episode I believe this show would have been a lot more enjoyable.


Audio: Great (9.0/10)

the music created by composer Kenji Kawai is in, my opinion, one of the best and most distinct soundtracks in anime joining my personal favourite OSTs alongside Evangelion, FLCL, Devilman: Crybaby, GitS and Kill la Kill

Every track has this feel of wonder and mystery attached to them, elevating every moment in which they are used in.

And Disillusion is one of the best OPs period.

The voice actors and actresses did a good job at portraying their characters.


Characters: (7.0/10)

the cast is quite large, consisting of the 14 participants of the holy grail war and a few other characters that aren't participants in the battle itself but are still relevant to the big picture.

Everyone is pretty distinct, well written and memorable with most of the relevant characters getting some good development.

All the villains, who are also participants in the war, are pretty well done with well defined and believable motivations and reasons for wanting the grail as well as the main cast which was likeable and well written.


Enjoyment: Good (7.0/10)

Fate/stay night is a pretty enjoyable anime that I would recommend to anyone who isn't fazed by below average animation and can enjoy it's other qualities.

It also has great rewatch value after you finish the main fate series


Overall Score: 7/10


Written on the 13th of February, 2019

I still remain to be a relative rookie in the world of anime, but I'm sure there are some things that have amazed others who are more familiar with anime just as much as they have amazed me.
And Fate/stay night was was one of those things.  This anime seems to have just about everything you could ever want in one well-wrapped package.  It's got a great story, action scenes that I believe rival or even surpass Dragonball, romance and a certain captivating effect on the viewer.
First off, I'd like to say the art is just magnificent.  The character designs in this animeare proof of that, and I must especially say that I loved Saber the most.  As a character, she seems enthralling and interesting at the same time, and you can help but be drawn in when you're watching her in all the fantastically executed swordfighting scenes.


If there is one thing I might have to say that this anime lacks, it would probably be the music.  Some of the songs were good, but most of them felt a little too slow for me, or they didn't exactly fit the scene.  This could all be personal taste, but I found myself just fast fowarding the beginning and ending sequences half the time.


On another note, I'd like to say that the story could have been done a little better. I understand that as an anime, there are many limitations to what they can do in only so many episodes.  I'm sure that there are many more things about the characters that they couldn't explore, simply because of the restricted time frame.  In the visual novel, which I have just begun, I expect that there is much more that is explored regarding the overall storyline


All in all, I believe this anime deserves a 9/10, because although it does approach perfection, it still has some things which bring it down just a little bit.  Nevertheless, it is beyond fantastic either way, and I highly reccomend it to just about anyone.  It does meet expectations, I think.


Hejin

I've heard a lot about this anime, so I assumed it should be good. I was wrong.
The anime is very talkative, and spends a lot of moments with characters talking about what they want to do, and a lot of talking during the fights itself. They don't really reveal a lot of what the character's motives are, but makes you think they are thinking real hard about very philosophical questions.
Fights ultimately boil down to a rather dull clash of swords that have little variety in pose and camera placement, and skill ultimates that are continually spammed again and again until they miraculously work. It isa bit like Ichigo of Bleach spamming his Getsuga again and again.\n\n
The show actually started on a better note, with a proper mystery and characters with a lot of personality. Somehow that got lost along the way, especially when a random loli appeared out of nowhere. Although I have no knowledge of the anime's source material, I think the show should have stuck to either doing it as a medieval fantasy fight, or a school-based supernatural mystery. At times, you have the feeling that it might be a slow-pacing supernatural mystery slice-of-life show, or a harem in disguise (especially when every girl ends up in the protagonist's house). It ended up as a mix between magic swordsmanship, sorcery, and school mystery.\n\n
I would not recommend this show. Not for its plot, nor its action or animation. If you do watch the show though, look out for Archer. I think he's a pretty interesting character that pretty much carried the show for me.

When talking about Deen's anime adaption of Fate Stay Night it can be a bit tricky. When compared to its source material it doesn't do the Visual Novel justice as it attempts to splice in parts of the other two routes(Unlimited Blade Works and Heaven's Feel) into it in attempt to tell a single story.
For the most part the anime follows the Fate route which focuses mainly on its heroine Saber but at the same doesn't really have a sense of direction till much later and is bogged down by a lot of original material.
The animation quality is certainly a mixed bag but certain momentsshow some splendor but other times feel dated but I felt that the music was rather nice with a few pieces that truly stick out.


When it comes to characters they are not fully explored and feel that they are missing important pieces of them that define who they are to the audience. One character that suffers from poor characterization the most is its protagonist Shirou Emiya whose "Stay in the kitchen" tendencies are flanderized to almost comical levels that it painted a poor picture of his character from the visual novel that's not to stay he was amazing in the first route but certainly better than what was given to us here.


I felt that its strongest moments were during its climatic finale and its portrayal of what I consider to be the visual novel's most powerful ending.


This isn't a bad anime its mostly average although there are those who are pretty attached to it which I can understand. In the end though I don't think its the best place to start if you are planning to jump into Fate Stay Night's world. However at the same time if you ever decide for yourself to watch it then do so as soon as you can because if you watch Fate Zero or the on going Unlimited Blade Works TV series the chances are you might have the urge to drop it.


In the end despite its short comings its a decent little anime but I recommend you find the Visual Novel believe me its a great experience.

Story: I'm not going to tell you any of the story just in case you watch it. I don't want to ruin it for you. I'll just tell you what I think. While the story was pretty captivating it just couldn't hold my attention too much because i guess you can say it was pretty typical anime characteristics of the main character being CRAZY weak and through really convenient circumstances and RANDOM bursts of strength win. I thought that was pretty lame honestly, So predictable. While there are a few plot twists everything just works out too well for the main character like "Wow, thisguy really beating me down but out of nowhere i remember what someone else says. NOW I CAN WIN".


Art: The series is very nice too look at. Everything is put together well and looks nice. The super moves are pretty vibrant, go big budgets go but nothing new here really.


Sound: Nothing really stuck out here other than being pretty crisp nothing sounded out of place so it was ok. Can't really say anything about it other than that BUT this series did have good voice acting I thought. The voices suited the characters pretty well.


Characters: They were ok but it was kinda annoying how the main character was weak like none other always telling people that were stronger than him not to fight. The magicians in this series weren't memorable at all. The main character was kinda lame until the end of the series which isn't acceptable in my opinion. The servants in this story were ok other than Saber and Archer. These two stuck out the most because of character development. Saber was a very enjoyable character due to how she reacts to certain situations and how she responds. Archer was well.....amazing. The coolest servant in my opinion. Cool, calm, collected. I just wished he had a bigger role because he was very cool. 


Enjoyment: It was ok but nothing I would recommend or show my friends. It didn't really excel at anything. The story was too convenient for the main characters so it kinda felt lame. The fighting was ok but didn't leave a lasting impression. Ya, there were a few enjoyable moments but the whole feeling of everything just magically falling into place kinda nagged at me the whole time.


Overall: TOO CONVENIENT!!! If your a person that likes everything working out MAGICALLY then I  definitely recommend this anime for you but for people that like suspense then well, this anime sucks in that department. I personally like plot twists that keep you hooked but when everything just happens with "random luck" ALL the time in favor for the main characters gets old really fast.

this anime is one of the best i've seen. with a dynamic plot and complex character development this anime promises to be more than just and average run of the mill series. this anime is a serious yet sometimes comedic at times and the character relationships are more along the mature side but only up to and maybe slightly higher than PG-13 rating with a few innuendoes thrown in. personally i think this series holds its value all the way through and keeps the story moving not fast but steady all the way to the end. it leaves you wanting a sequel, 10 out of10 for me and im sure this is one anime that will not become indefeasible.

Fate/stay night is the 2006 sequel to Fate/Zero. As the UFOtable remake is airing within the next month, I figured I'd review this version to segway into the newer version.
Story: Blah blah blah Holy Grail War blah blah blah *insert generic plot twist here* blah blah blah. There's your explanation of the story. Satire aside, the premise is very intriguing and the execution could have been worse. There are a few rather expected plot twists here and there, but for the most part, the Fate route of the novel (being the one this adaptation was based on) feels like a shounen with a few moremature bits. The first 10 episodes or so are very filler-ridden and really detract from the overall story. The ending, while being predictable, was very well done.




Art: The art is... well... bad. Even for 2006, it was bad. It was bad then, it always has been bad, it always will be bad. The character models themselves are very good, albeit rather low quality and scratchy. The fight scenes seem to be where DEEN's budget went, as they look a level above the rest of the show. They are actually very impressive for 2006, and when compared to the rest of the show, they are miles ahead.




Sound: The composition for this one is rather forgettable, and the voice acting for the dub is rather average. Not much to say here.



Characters: The characters are as follows: Shirou Emiya, the main character. He is a typical "I want to save everyone" type of character and his ideals never really change through the show. He is also a huge idiot, throwing himself at danger at the drop of a hat. Rin Tohsaka is a classmate of Shirou's who explains the Holy Grail war to him and guides him through the war. In this route, at least, I thought that her reasoning for helping Shirou was rather weak. At first, I figured she was the love interest, but nothing really ever happened with that. (Most likely because this is a visual novel and she has her own route anyways.) The last character is Saber. Saber is Shirou's servant, being a very noble and proud medieval knight. She is very stubborn in her ideals, and ends up being the series' love interest. I thought this was the weakest way to go route-wise, as Saber really belongs as her own character, not just a love interest for Shirou.




Enjoyment: With all its faults, I still enjoyed the series. If you have watched Fate/Zero, can't wait for UBW 2014, or don't want to play the VN, I would recommend this one to you. Although it isn't extremely well executed, it is definitely worth watching to get the idea of Fate/stay night.



Overall: This show is a stark contrast to Fate/Zero. It has a much lighter tone, that most likely due to the fact that 1). It is based on a harem VN and 2). It was written long before Fate/Zero, and Type-Moon's writers have much improved since then. I would recommend it to anyone who, as previously stated, has watched Fate/Zero and can't wait for Fate/stay night 2014, or if you want an easier way into the Fate series than Fate/Zero or even the VN.

This one's an infamous one. Fate/Stay Night was a Visual Novel written by Typ-Moon. It was really damn good. Then there was an anime adaptation and let's just say fans of the VN don't like it that much. But is it really as bad as everyone says? Let's find out.
Story: 
The Anime adapts the first route of the game, the Fate route, which is probably my second favorite route overall. Everything seems fine so far, but there's a problem. For whatever reason, DEEN decided to add a bunch of stuff from the other routes: Unlimited Blade Works and Heaven's Feel. So for instance, you getsome of Sakura's backstory from HF, and you also get stuff like the Caster subplot from UBW (All of it heavily abridged, mind you)

The problem is that this makes the pacing slow down to a crawl, and considering the already slow pacing of the Fate route due to all of the exposition dumps, this is a massive problem. Also, it basically goes against the whole point of the Fate route and it being an otherwise straightforward story.

But ultimately... it's still the Fate route, I can't stay mad at it for too long. And honestly, for everything this anime does wrong, it does something right. The emotional moments are all excellently adapted, to the point I straight up cried in the finale (I did cry in the VN, but only after seeing the Last Episode, which is basically an epilogue to the Fate route) And all of the comedic moments are mostly well done. And when it simply tires to be an adaptation of the Fate Route and nothing else, it's great. They even made a slight improvement by actually showing Archer's last stand against Berserker.


Characters:


Okay, let's get the obvious out of the way: Shirou is severely simplified from his VN counterpart, who was a deconstruction of Vanilla Protgonists, which are mostly male Light Novel protagonist las nowadays. You still get some of that here, but not until the last couple of episodes, which really showcases how he's ultimately just an empty shell who despises the people around him dying instead of him. He's not terrible, but damn does the lack of his internal monologue hurt his character.

The rest thankfully get a better treatment. Since the Fate route is occasionally referred to as the Saber route, it stands to reason that Saber gets a lot of development, and she does. It's amazing seeing her go from such a cold and seemingly selfless person into a warm and caring woman with seemingly selfless motives, but are ultimately selfish in nature. Her relationship with Shirou was really well done. Seeing the two go through the many trials and tribulations to acknowledge their feelings for each other (Especially Saber as she's pretty much constantly in denial about her own feelings for almost the entirety of the show) and by the end I just wanted to give them a hug.

The rest of the characters are all great too. From the hot tempered and sarcastic Rin, the callous and pragmatic Archer, the gloriously arrogant Gilgamesh, to, of course, the hound of Ireland himself, Lancer. The only character I didn't care for is Sakura, but even then, she's enough of a minor character for me to ignore it. And trust me, she is far, FAR worse once we get to Heaven's Feel because... I have issues with that route.


Animation:


Remember how I complained about the lackluster animation in Berserk 1997? Well, this show's basically the same, except somehow even worse! At least Berserk was mostly on-model. Here, things go off-model very often, especially early on. It does get better towards the end, but not much.


Sound: 


By contrast the soundtrack is amazing. It's basically the VN's soundtrack, but with a few glorious remixes thrown in. Yeah, its not much, but hey, the VN's soundtrack was already perfect. The openings and endings are pretty good, with "Disillusion" being probably my favorite of the bunch.


Voice acting:


All of the Seiyuus from the game return and do a pretty good job. Major props to Ayako Kawasumi as Saber and Noriaki Sugiyama as Shirou, as without them, Shirou and Saber's relationship wouldn't had been as good as it is. The rest do a good job too, of particular mention is Kana Ueda as Rin, for as this was her first major role and she does a great job too. Same goes for everyone else, from Hiroshi Kamiya, Tomokazu Seki, Atsuko Tanaka, Nobutoshi Canna, to even the voice of Alucard himself, Joji Nakata.


Overall:


So, is Fate/Stay Night deserving of all the hate? No, not even close. However, it is ultimately a lackluster adaptation of an excellent Visual Novel. If you want to check it out, do so if you want, but really, you should just read the VN if you get the chance.


Final Score: 7/10

Fate/stay night
Prior to watching this anime, I watched and made a review about Fate/Zero. As I finished Fate/Zero, my expectations for this anime were extremely high. I seriously thought that this would be and uber awesome anime, but boy was I wrong. It might have been a mistake in my part to watch Fate/Zero first but still, I am very disappointed. I will try not to spoil anything so please bear with me if I don’t put too many details.Now before you click the not helpful button, let’s get on to the review.
While I was reading a few comments about Fate/Stay Night, some of themwere praising about how awesome it was but the way I see it, Fate/Stay Night is a highly overrated anime. To start off, the story itself seemed off. The pacing was horrible, the story was unclear, and the way it suddenly change genre in the middle of the story was just absolutely terrible. The story started off incredibly slow that I had to force myself just to get through it, hoping that it would get better somewhere in the middle. Then it did speed up in the middle, but it sped up way too much that there wasn’t enough time to explain some concepts regarding the main objects of the story like the Holy Grail, noble phantasms and even the magic they use. After that it took a turn for the worse. A story focused on action suddenly takes a sharp turn and desperately tries to emulate a love story, which was just terrible. Not that I’m saying that a little romance is bad but a little too much that it affects the story is not good. And just when the story was reaching its climax, the antagonist just dies and there, end of the story. It was so disappointing because just when I thought that it was getting good it suddenly ends, leaving a bitter taste in my mouth. 


There is also a problem when it comes to the characters. The main Protagonist, Emiya was too weak. He was a pathetic excuse for a righteous hero. All he did was serve as a meat shield and a love interest for the main heroine, Saber and BAM, shit happens. Aside from that, he is also so damn stupid that it’s unbearable(I mean seriously, “people die when they are killed” wtf, no shit Sherlock?). Saber in my opinion, was a good character from the start. Serious, stoic, and just badass but then Emiya makes a sacrifice for her a couple of times and from a badass character, she turns into a tsundere that blushed EVERY FUCKING TIME that she’s alone with Emiya(obvious sarcasm here people). The rest of the characters are Rin, Sakura, Ilya and that other annoying woman. I only mentioned them because they weren’t really given enough time to develop into proper characters. Heck, even the main antagonist, Gilgamesh and his master(won’t mention the name, major spoiler) were given so little time that I never even felt like they were there. I mean like seriously, Gilgamesh, being the main antagonist was only shown in like only like six out of twenty-four episodes, SIX! And during those six episodes, he had like only 60 minutes of screen time, certainly not enough for viewers to build strong feelings for him. So when he died, it felt like nothing happened.


To top it off, the graphics were terrible and so is the music although it can easily be overlooked considering that the anime was made in 2005. it can’t really be judged with today’s standards so i just decided to overlook it.


Overall, I think that it really is a big disappointment in my part. As I watched Fate/Zero, my expectation was very high, only to be crushed by a mediocre anime. As I’ve mentioned before, it really is an overrated anime that was a little ambitious and failed to deliver what it tried to bring. That is why I only give it a 6/10

Sometimes I wonder why I shouldn't just want animes whose review were really high. That way, the chances of them being good would be much better and I don't have to sit through those animes that weren't all that great. Fate/Stay Night is one of those animes that I wished I had seen sooner because it was definitely one of the better animes out there. With high reviews from my other reviewers, it certainly not only met but exceeded my expectations.
Review
Story
   I think after watching animes all these years, animes that combines action, magic, a little of romance and comedyare the types that I much prefer to watch. This anime fits all of those needs. With an action pacted story sequence and a slow by developing love connection, it certainly made me happy to see it contains all the elements I prefer.


   The overall scenario of the plot isn't something new, a big fight every so years to determine the fate of the world, but it certainly has enough of its own uniqueness to prevent it from being dull. The story goes like this. A battle for the Holy Grail occurs every now and then to determine who is worthy enough to receive the Holy Grail. Upon receive the Holy Grail, the "Master" and the "Servant" are granted one wish. However, something usual happened in the last Holy Grail War that ultimately continued onto the next. What it is, I won't say to prevent any further spoiling of the plot. But imagine this, how would you react if King Authur was a female? How would you react if instead of being the King Arthur everyone looked up to, this King Authur was looked downed upon because she couldn't lead?


   Without going into any further details (and if you haven't noticed already, most of my reviews now are very incomplete when it comes to the story), this plot of this anime is certainly worth watching. And I am not just saying that because this happens to be of the genres of animes that I liked. I am saying it because it was actually good. The plot moves on with a nice flow to it and each little thing that occurs only adds to it.


Characters


   Following in the covention of most animes of this type, this anime has all the characters you would expect: a brave and noble warrior, a person whose brains are beyond normal, a character with a sad past, and a hero who is useless at the start but becomes cruicial by the end. While I end up liking most of the characters, I must say that I was not totally impressed with the development of some of them. At times, the development just seemed too slow and there are still quite a few amount of questions I have regarding these characters. Unfortunately, I will probably never get the answers to them because there doesn't seem to be a sequel of any sorts.


   One of the things I look for in animes is how the characters interact with each other and how they got that way. Does it seem reasonable for one character to fall in love with another? What is it about that other character that would allowed this love connection. Every action has a consequence and every consequence is the product of an action. So, I really don't like animes that has one character being totally devoted to another character without some kind of reason. With that long rant aside, for the most part, I felt that this anime was able to do just that. Provide enough information that if this was real (I know, this isn't real but when it comes to human interactions, it should be), these individuals would behave the same way.


Animation


   Near flawless. I am actually watching other animes that were being produced at the same time as this anime and I can see a clear difference it quality between them. The characters look good and so do the surrounding. The fight scenes are well done and that makes it quite exciting. The only complaints I have is that some of the scenes were a little too dark (though it was during the night so I am just asking for too much).


Sound


   The truth is, I actually heard the first opening theme of this anime a long time before I even watched it. That song was one of the best I have heard at the time and still does to this day. Really nice vocals though the lyrics doesn't really match up with the beat. The ending theme I am not too excited about but it is really bad either. The rest of the background music is good as well though I might need to get back to you on that once I get a chance to finish listening to the soundtrack.


   I didn't had any complaints about the voice of the characters either. There isn't something where like other animes where some of the characters voice sounds like they are constantly whining.


Conclusion


  A very good anime by all means. Personally, I thought it could go a lot longer and from the looks of it, there does not seem to be a sequel happening in the future. Too bad because I really liked this anime. My suggestion to you who are reading this review is to watch this anime if you haven't. It will certainly be worth your time.

I'm not a virtual novel follower, therefore I had watched Fate/Stay Night without any basis of the show besides my own viewing of ufotable's Fate/Zero adaptation. In fact, I was unaware of anything much about this anime adaptation, and it was a rather blind pick. I'm quite glad I chose it. Being that I recently viewed this anime, I hadn't been around for the hype train that supposedly existed, therefore having no expectations. 
Here's my breakdown:
Story: 8
Follows the same Holy Grail War setting and takes place in the Nasuverse. The biggest difference I found between this and F/Z is that the setting and story ismore immature, which isn't a bad thing per se. It simply takes on a different tone. Follows a predictable yet alluring narrative which leads to an excellent climactic finish.


Art: 8

Considering it's a 2006 anime, the art is excellent, budget considered. Fights and characters are flashy, nothing super out of the ordinary like our recent counterpart, but solid, aesthetic animation.


Sound: 10

Music seems to capture the essence of every scene flawlessly. No complaints.


Characters: 9

Most people seemed to have nitpicked this the most. To be frank, I enjoyed the cliches and honestly didn't mind the lack of development in certain characters after understanding that there are different heroines in each route. Shiro, in all his cliche, "I don't know what I'm doing but let's save the world" character, serves as a solid staple for the basis of Rin, Saber, and Sakura. Saber is a lovely protagonist who receives much desired development from F/Z. While certain development issues do take away the 10 here, I found the characters to be memorable and enjoyable.


Enjoyment: 9

I thoroughly enjoyed every moment of this anime. While sometimes the pacing was off, everything else was spot on for me.


Overall: 9

By no means perfect, F/SN is a fun, immature predecessor to F/Z. If you're looking for a casual, easy, fun watching experience, F/SN is a tremendous choice.

Where to start... First of all I will say that I jumped into this anime with fairly high expectations even if it was adapted on a 12 year old VN 9 years ago.
**Animation** there were no problems with the animations. At times I even felt chills run through my neck just cause how good the fighting was done. Overall very good especially seeing as it was from 2006.
**Sound** the soundtrack is really good, and the voice acting is also really good especially if you factor in that it was originally an Visual Novel which often means worse voice actors.
**Story** The story was overall well done,but at times felt like it jumped certain parts but all in all a good adaptation of a VN, something that can be hard to say nowadays.\n\n
**Characters** For the characters, well I kind of liked them kind of didn't, i guess, I liked Rin and Saber, but the "side" characters that was Sakura and Taiga Fujimura felt most of the time unnecesary and simply in the way.\n
As for the main character himself, Emiya Shirou. I simply did not like him, at all many of the times. He felt really sexist and on at the sam time he was kind of like the annoying typical shonen hero type who'd not kill anyone and do everything by himself. He felt childish and annoying.\n\n
**Enjoyment** During the first few arcs I really had a hard time actually watching the anime, it felt mostly like a drag and it was boring to watch. But as the anime went on i grew to like it and by no means is it a bad anime, it's was just really not what I thought it would be. Something that was said very good was " It's a 24 episode series with an animation budget for 12 episodes and a story that could have been 39 episodes long. You do the math." and that really is the story of the anime, Aditionally to me it also felt somewhat sexist which I personally disliked and I usually does not notice these stuff.\n\n
But all in all it's worth watching, if not for just this anime but for the coming sequels and cause of all the talk going on around the anime. But you should probably watch it when you have time and when you feel that there is no other anime that would take your time. \n
In the end I give it a 7.5/10

Length: 24 episodes
Original Airdates: 1/06 - 6/06
Demographic: Seinen
Genres: Adventure, Drama, Fantasy, Romance, Supernatural
Plot Synopsis
Shirou Emiya lost his parents in a fire when he was young and was later adopted by a sorceror by the name of Kiritsugu Emiya. Although he was full of admiration for his adopted father and yearns to become an ally of justice, Shirou has limited powers and was unable to become a strong sorceror like his father. That is until one fateful day, he was drawn into the Holy Grail War and had to summon a female "Servant" known as Saber in order to protect himself. It turns out that theHoly Grail War involves a series of battles among powerful sorcerors to fight for the possession of a relic that will grant one's wishes, the Holy Grail. There are altogether seven "Masters" who can summon their respective "Servants" from different classes known as Saber, Archer, Rider, Berserker, Lancer, Caster and Assasin. These "Servants" have to hide their names in order not to reveal their weaknesses to the enemies. The story revolves around Shirou and his entanglement in the Holy Grail War.\n
(From Anime News Network)\n\n
Personal Opinion\n
I actually tried to watch this anime a month ago... but the first episode was not enough to keep me interested.   I had a feeling that i had dropped it too easily so i recently picked it up again. The 2nd episode was enough to get me interested.\n
Okay, so if you want a good story, pretty good characters, and some nice fights... this is the anime for you.  I mean I tried to look for something wrong w/ this anime... and I can't find one... Yet... it didn't grab me like some other stuff i've watched.  Interesting, yes... just not my kind of anime\n\n
7/10\n\n
Similar to...\n

Relationship btw magician master, and sword-wielding servent\n\n
-Shaman King\n
A tournament btw supernatural players

Fate/stay night's anime adaptation is somewhat of a wild card in the Fate series. Some people praise it, while others bash on this adaptation. However, although not as strong as an entry as say, Zero, I still found this adaptation to be enjoyable. The main argument that comes across when talking about this series is how the visual novel is much better than the adaptation here. I myself have not played the visual novel, so this may be the result of my differing experience.
Story: Fate stay/night delivers a story that is rich in detail, and deep at certain points. It has a fairly good balancebetween fights and character development, but there's one gaping thing holding it back: time. This adaptation suffers from not having enough episodes to fit certain and concise endings to the events that they want. Also, I felt that some battles ended with some sort of "deus-ex machina" sort of thing, where one thing ends the battle very quickly. However, if you look past this, the story itself is very well handled and executed, albeit with flaws.


Art: From a modern perspective, the art obviously shows some age. But in a perspective from 2006, the art is amazing. The animation is slightly choppy at times, but it's probably the best that I've seen from that year. There's not much else I can say here, so I'll move onto Sound.


Sound: What can I say? Voice acting is high quality. The music is also what you'd expect from a Fate series title, and captures the moment. I also like the first opening, a lot. 


Character: With character, the show seems to fall behind a little.The main characters are developed as always, but what seems to lack is in the supporting cast. Whereas the later entries into the series show promise in all characters, once a character has filled their role in hindering the plot, this show just tosses them aside. Illya went from an actual threat to a random kid that Shirou had to deal with until the war ended, which could have been part of the VN, but I felt that she could have been used for more. I also felt the Kotomine wasn't really used effectively here. Although realised in Zero, here, he's more or less a final boss trope that doesn't have any real story. 


Enjoyment: There were some hindrances that did impede on my experience, but overall this show was engaging and very enjoyable to watch.


Overall: If you're a fan of the Fate series, I do recommend you watch this show, although with an open mind. However, I would not say that this is a good first entry. But, if you're in a mood to watch anything, consider giving this a try.

To 'Fate/Stay Night',
You were the first anime I ever watched and I used to absolutely love you, and your soundtrack stands as one of the most atmospheric in anime for me to this day! However, you haven't aged well at all. Your animation's very clunky and the details are lacking much of the time. I was willing to forgive you, but you're just so barren of events. You try to deliver a slow character-intensive thrilling experience, but you just absolutely fail to deliver. Rin stands as an exposition dump this time around for basically the entire series. The characters basically just voice their worries, howgood the food is, and how clueless the MC is in every conversation. I also didn't remember your romance being as ham-fisted as it was. As I have a lot of nostalgia for you, I did find a bit of charm in it, but I knew every second that I was dealing with some cheesy and hilarious stuff. How Saber is portrayed is part of the problem, she's like an emotionless robot. And why did they all have to be eating whenever there was a long conversation, and why was Sakura even there? You're just too oldie otaku-pandering for me nowadays with all your plot skin-ship fanservice and the way in-which Saber says "master" to the MC like a maid.


There needs to be more action, more focus on drama beyond Shirou's clearly-flawed ideals. You're just an anime for a younger me I suppose. But I have to say, if anyone else read this, that if they typed in "Unmei no Yoru" on YouTube and listened to it, that there is no anime in existence that will come to my mind but you. Some of your soundtracks are just so perfect for the setting, and I should mention the start was actually pretty well-done (around the first 3-4 episodes). There is also a few cool and interesting moments, but you're just too flawed of an experience for me to lend you more than a 4/10...


A review with love,

Piegoose


P.S. Watch the first 3 episodes, than the Unlimited Blade Works movie for a 7/10 experience

The story of Fate/Stay Night is deceptively simple, but it's the many events that make the show a little bit more complex than it might seem like. Naturally, the meat-and-gravy parts are generally related to the battles the players will have to engage in during the war. But Fate/Stay Night also seems to relish keeping -- and eventually revealing -- secrets. Expect a lot of "the truth isn't quite like it seems at first" scenes to pop in every now and then, especially as the show draws to a close. Allignment shifts are almost a given during the many face-offs, some of which might comeacross as more ridiculous than the others.


In another note, the battles are generally nice to look at. Most of them are actual physical combat, and since we are talking about characters that generally adhere to their given summoning names -- Saber, Archer, Lancer, Assassin -- battles do take on different flairs from time to time. There are a few cases of "my schwarz is bigger than yours" kamehameha™ fights near the end, but thankfully, those are few and generally quickly over with. The anime also ends conclusively, which is another thing to be thankful about, although titles that generally overstay their welcome mostly center around harem or big shounen fight titles, wherein Fate/Stay Night might fit into both in some way, but only barely so.


So yeah, I enjoyed this show. Even if I had to resort to reading Wiki articles and the likes about the characters to get the full picture, I see no reason why I should consider Fate/Stay Night any less than good, if not great, entertainment.


Fights, secrets, plots -- it's enough of either in here to make most people happy, I should think.


Shirou is a self-styled Champion of Justice. Not of the mask-wearing, cape-sporting variety, but of the quietly helpful, self-sacrificing, unyieldingly principled variety. The only survivor of a tragedy that cut a swath of destruction through his town ten years earlier, he witnesses an altercation between two supernaturally skilled warriors, and is soon drawn into a battle between seven magi and their seven Servants, resurrected legendary warriors from around the world. Paired with a powerful female Servant known only as Saber, Shirou must take his place as the seventh, and last, of the magi.


Recommended Audience: Naturally, there'll be violence, even a little bit bloody one. The redstuffs doesn't splatter all over the place, though, but viewer caution is recommended. There's also some darker imagery regarding a shield of some sort meant to drain students of mana, which has.... bad consequences for a local school. In other words, nothing too excessive.

This anime is great, despite the main character and his stupid eye brows and ideals of "protecting everything". Plus, the annoying thing is that they show the same flashbacks a few times through out the show and the protagonist always talks about protectiong stuff. 
The story is confusing at first, but at the end everything comes together. Its basicly about 7 masters who kill each other with servants/magic, and the last one standing obtains the Holy Grail. And a weir browed looking kid who falls in love with his servant. Blah Blah. 
Overall this anime is enjoyable. Just ignore those fucking eyebrows T_T.

Fate/Stay Night isn't that bad. Sure the art leaves a lot to be desired, and the plot is pretty thin, but that doesn't mean it is bad.
I had fun watching it, and while it pales in comparison to the Visual Novel, I didn't hate it.
The biggest problem is the art is horrible. I mean it looks terrible. The studio could have done much better but some characters just look plain awful. And the CG dragon was just looked retarded.
And then the story. Mixing the Fate Route, Unlimited Blade Works Route, and Heaven's Fell Route just doesn't work. It would have been much better had itbeen three seasons, each season dedicated to a different route. Or the Fate Route, so then people would read the Visual Novel to find out what happens in the others.


On the other hand the sound is amazing. I loved both the OP, the ED, the voices. Everything was perfect. Especially Archer's voice during the fight with Berserker.


The characters were good, although the development is lacking. This may be due to the fact it is not as descriptive as a book, but it could also be that some characters, especially Sakura, don't get enough screen time.


I enjoyed it though. A lot of moments were really cool and the fights were the most well done parts of the series.


If you liked this, then go buy the Visual Novel, it is SOO much better and you will love it.

Disclaimer: I base my overall ratings on emotional impact, therefore the final score of this review will be highly subjective. However, with individual ratings I try to be more objective.
This is also coming from someone who has not read the Fate/Stay Night visual novel, or seen/read any other Fate/ related media.
Art – 9
This probably deserves a 10, but I just couldn’t get past the fact that some of the wider scenes just looked so odd because the character quality diminished. Obviously this is because you can only draw so much detail on an A4(?) piece of paper and the fact that the rest of theart is incredibly high caliber makes it’s shortcomings forgiveable.


I really appreciated the close up shots of the servants, especially saber. So much has gone into her character design and the metallic look of her armour is just superb. The character designs are original and really nice to look at too, without conforming to any particular style.


There were a couple of 3D scenes which look awful but I can’t rate this any less than a 9 because it looked so fantastic.


Animation – 10

I’ll just leave this here… (minor spoilers as to a servant saber fights, but just watch that from 36 seconds for a bit, it’s insane)

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uVJKo4nMaTo#t=00m36s


Sound – 10


There should be an extra tier just for Fate/Stay Night’s music; it’s absolutely incredible.


Fate/Stay Night’s soundtrack consists mostly of stunningly beautiful vocals and clarinets, which really sells the medieval fantasy feel surrounding Saber. La Sola, the vocal piece that plays during the (intricately constructed) final scene is just beautiful. This is - in my opinion - the best vocal piece of music I have ever heard and in terms of anime is more beautiful than Elfen Lied's opening, Lilium. Also of note is Mozart’s Lacrimosa, sung by a single vocalist which is absolutely mesmerising. Considering the entire soundtrack manages to be on par with a Mozart piece, I'm just shocked.


The soundtrack is amazing.


Story - 8

Now this is a very controversial topic but in all honesty I can't pick any glaring faults in Fate/Stay Night's story. I thought Fate/Stay Night had a really solid story up until about episode 16. The lore is a great strong suit of this show. Having all the servants rooted in history makes this so much more relatable and makes who Saber actually is, that much cooler.


Now I won’t lie, I don’t watch this show primarily for the action, I watch Fate/Stay Night because of the romance. I particularly appreciate the use of subtext, which is not often used in anime.


I won’t give away who the couple is, but this is one of the few anime where you cannot immediately pick the couple. You might, but it’s not blatantly suggested and it takes the entire length of the show for the romance to build which is perfect. Too often in anime romance just happens way too quickly but in Fate/Stay Night it is paced perfectly, building and building in an exponential way before the beautiful, beautiful payoff at the end.


One thing I noticed (also that many anime fail at) is that Fate/Stay Night uses violence to great effect. It only uses the exact right amount for the amount of emotion it wants to elicit. There is one particular scene towards the end – now I won’t go into detail, but needless to say, it’s one of the most violent scenes in the show which heightens the emotion of the scene, creating one of the most powerful scenes in the whole show. It has some very, very memorable scenes and I'm honestly not sure why people don't appreciate its merits for what they are.


I’m not sure what people are on about when they say the pacing was off, I’m thinking those people were just impatient that there wasn’t an epic action scene each episode. This series has one of the best uses of foreshadowing I’ve ever seen. Things are revealed, but out of context and as such, nothing is spoiled but makes it that much more amazing when the foreshadowing is paid off. I very much like the almost slice-of-life feel towards the start of the show and the transition into a more action-oriented style towards the end.


I thought this series was paced really well and really tightly written for a 24 episode series. Generally anime over 12 or 13 episodes tend to have little bits of filler here and there, but everything included in Fate/Stay Night advanced the story and/or the characters; nothing was out of place.


I’ll finish this section with the comment that the ending was kind of cliché, which really saddened me because I loved every other element of this anime.


Characters - 9


Shirou. Everyone seems to hate him and that may be because at first, he seems cliché. But one thing Studio DEEN did to help this was have people mock him and have the world disagree with his hero complex. Furthermore, at least his motivation was clear as to why he wanted to be a cliché ‘champion of justice’. Also, having watched the dub (which was really quite good; Kate Higgins was born to play Saber), I didn't get any of the 'people die when they are killed' nonsense.


The same was with the main bad guy (I won’t name names), though I really didn’t like him. He had his motivation, but I just couldn’t shake the feeling that he was really cliché.


Saber was really interestingly written. I love the way she seems stoic and emotionless, yet she’s actually a very complex character with inner and outer conflict.


Rin was just great. And I think I’ll end it there, whew…


Emotional impact/Enjoyment – 10

While this review may be more subjective because Fate/Stay Night was one of the first anime I watched, I still enjoy it immensely. I'm absolutely befuddled as to why people think it's so average. Just watch the final scene, with La Sola playing and TRY not to cry.

Know when you watch something so good it gives you chill down your spine and when it over you fell happy and sad at the same time?  For me that was Fate/Stay Night. The ending wasn't really all that cliche as most typical stories of the same genre, it had a sort of brilliance and epic foresight with in the final moments. Fate Stay Night is one of those story where it pull you know and gets you involved in the story. When it's over you just seem to want more and more cause of the attachment you make over the episodes. Fate StayNight is a gem of anime and an anime lover would be a fool to not watch this.


The Story is exceptionally original in my opinion.


The Art was well done.


The sound literally blew me away on how well it matched into the scenes


The Character development was excellent. The development between the 2 character was extremely inspiring like you wanted it to happen to you.

So I decided to review this 'cause it's really overrated and wanted people to know it's overrated.  Anyways...
___CHARACTERS___
Any story needs good characters to carry a good story, however no matter how good the story is, if the characters suck so will the story. This is the case with Fate/Stay Night. Most of the characters are flat with little to no character development. Let me breakdown some of the main characters so you have an understanding as to why they suck.
Shirou: Weirdly both the best and worst character in the anime. Let me explain what I mean. He gets the most character development, he findshis reasons to fight and why he wants the grail so he isn't bad in that respect. However I find it really hard to sympathize  and root for this guy because he totally unrealistic and annoying (This is subjective so guess this is why people might like this anime.). He will help help anyone out at all costs and doesn't even remotely care about his life. It's taken to the extreme when (Spoilers)  he pushes Saber out the way of a fatal blow and sacrifices himself. The thing is though he has known her for less than a day (End). I really could go on and on about his MANY flaws and self-contradictions but I think I will move on.


Rin: Honestly she wasn't bad but she practically zero character development. Did she love Shirou? Why did she want the grail? Why does she even help him? I guess I will never know.


Archer: LOL. This guy is considered a main character. All his screen time consists of are a few fights and those where he tells Shiro he is a little bitch with silly ideals.


Saber: She is probably the best character. Wants to get shit done and  somewhat decent character development. Not much else to say really.


Everyone else: Awful, just awful. No character development and really generic. Hell one bad guys reason for fighting for the grail is "I want the grail 'cause I can and I don't mind murdering thousands of people for it".Truth be told he didn't actually say that but he might as well of.


___STORY___


This was really poor. For a seven way battle it is rather convenient that all the bad guys line themselves up for Shirou and Saber to beat one by one. It's frustrating to watch as I know they can't lose so it takes away all the tension and build-up.


 Example (Spoilers): Saber is fighting that big guys with all those lives (his name has alluded me sorry :P) and is losing badly. Doesn't mean shit 'cause it ends up Shirou is so op that he can make anything with his mind that can beat anyone instantly. *Facepalms*


It's a Harem.


___ART//SOUND___


I don't really have much to say because they weren't bad at all, actually decent. I guess the most notable thing is that the op was good, not amazing but still somewhat memorable.


___CONCLUSION___


Would I recommend this? Maybe if you don't think Shirou annoying douchebag. I want to say that I LOVE Fate/Zero and i think that it is truly brilliant and it's a shame that it has any connection to Fate/Stay Night. Glad I could finally get this off my chest :P


This is my first review so feedback would great. Thanks for reading.

Sound:7 (Good)
Character:5 (Mediocre)
Enjoyment:7 (Good)
Overall:7 (Good)
Well,for those who just started the series with /stay night,you might allude some problems,like the protagonist being completely useless,but let's don't get into spoilers.
I recommend you to watch theseries,starting with /stay night for a reason some people would say It's pointless:Because If you can get through 24 episodes of a dumb main character,an oldie Art that might bother some people,and a kind-of-slow pace,everything else will be wonderful.Unless you came to watch a Romance anime with a big backstory,you will be a bit disappointed with what you might've been looking for.\n
But not everything is so bad.Fights are a bit more interesting than they would seem,and if you like character development,for god's sake you'll get it.And other protagonists (Which aren't Emiya Shirou,the main character) get along with the story quite good.At least that's a big part of why I enjoyed Fate/Stay night.But as I'd like to repeat,It's not that good.

After watching Fate/Stay Night I have this urge to write a review just to put my thoughts in order. 
The reason I rate it 6 (if not lower) is because I fell in the hype-trap. EVERYONE kept telling me watch the Fate series, thus my expectations for it went through the roof. That explains its downfall in my rating score. If I didn't consider it to be a must-watch anime, then my score prooobably would have been higher. But hey, the higher you get the harder you fall. 
Story: 8
For me the story was the best element in the anime. We've seen before in otheranime the formula of gathering several warriors/people to fight for a prize (Mirai Nikki, Btooom etc) but this time it's being done with the help of ancient heroes. As a Greek I must say, including Greek mythology in an anime was quite exciting and I really liked the small twists they made to those myths, otherwise it would have been proper plagarism and not really exciting to watch. Anyways, every ten years or so, 7 heroes appear to the world in order to acquire the Holy Grail- a chalice that will grand any wish you want. To get it, they have to kill each other until only one hero stands. However, every hero makes a pact with a Master (someone who can use magic) and together they try to win the Holy Grail War. And here comes our Main Character Emiya Shirou, who by pure luck (later we'll find out its his super thick plot armor) summons Saber, a swordswoman who was a hero of the past. 


That pretty much it for the plot. Tried to avoid any spoilers so I hope it doesn't seem too boring.


Characters: 5


Let's talk about Shirou, the Naruto of Fate/stay night. Like Naruto yelling SASUKE all the time, Shirou screams "SABER" every single episode. And ironically enough, the voice actor of Shirou is the same aaaas.....Sasuke! 


The short version is that Shirou has a DEATHWISH!! Can't explain it any other way. He has a super powerful hero to assist him and all he does is WALK AROUND THE CITY WITHOUT HER PROTECTING HIM. Like hell man, he knows the other masters want to kill him and he decides to wander unprotected. Btw he is useless too the max, can't use magic, fails all the time and drags others along with his stupidity. And the annoying part is the show tries to portay him as a justice protector who will fight evil whenever he sees it. Well sh*t, his actions show the complete opposite. Super impulsive, NEVER EVER asks for help and in the end EVERYTIME he needs help and ignores other peoples' warnings. And no, it's not like he goes alone fights the bad guy, inflicts serious damage and then he needs help. If it was a game he goes from Full HP to 1 (several times 0 ) in a matter of seconds and the opponent doesn't even get a scar.


All this of course get overshadowed by his UNBELIEVINGLY UNPENETRATABLE SUPER THICK PLOT ARMOR. You know he is the MC when he dies and revives dies and revives. As for his character, not really much to say, he is your average Shonen hero with little or no character development. 


As for the female protagonist, Saber's character is muuuuch better than Shirou's. Although her character development happens through flashbacks, they get justified with her decisions. I'm afraid I will spoil too much so I better stop here. Just so you know she is Overpowered ;)


There are other characters in the series (duh) but they get little backstory to explain their actions so you just have to go with the flow and accept their decisions and behaviour.


Art: 5


I will only say this... Have you seen a CG dragon before. If not be psychologically and mentally prepared. If yes please try to remember it, because this one will make you question even more human decision... Other than than, the art was neither good nor bad. It was what it was :p 


Music: 7


For sure if you have ever heard an anime OST compilation you would have heard the Fate soundtrack. It is so good and powerful that makes boring scenes interesting and stupid Shirou moments exciting. It doesn't get a 10 because it feels it's being recycled again and again in the anime. You will hear the same fight music in pretty much every fight but damn it's good music :)


Overall: 6


I enjoyed it for its unique plot, awesome soundtrack and in my opinion Saber saved the whole series. If not for her I would wish Shirou was the main villain so he gets killed in the most epic way. But of course this idiot will not die because of his ENORMOUS PLOT ARMOR. Yes the anime has many plot holes and unexplained stuff but I guess it's ok?! I would suggest to avoid the hype at least for Fate/Stay Night and go with a clear mind. Otherwise you will fall sooo hard you will probably hate the whole Fate series.


And as the amazing Shirou says "People die if they are killed"

This review is coming from someone who watched Fate/Zero first. This is also my first review so bare with me.
Personally, I loved Fate/Zero. It told a story of a game of life and death. The players were divers. Coming from all over the globe, they ranged from Assassins, and naive teenagers, to child murders and people trying to save their family. They were paired with some of the greatest heroes/villains from history and were forced to fight. The game was brutal. Even if you lost the game, and try to walk away, you're still not safe.
When I heard there was a sequel, I was superexcited. I shouldn't have been. The ultimate battle to the death turned into a stupid children squabble. Literally! Just about all the contestants were prepubescent children with unstable emotions. It was more a shitty high school love story than an actual fight. And for some stupid reason, they just happen to be from the same area in Japan. What is up with that.\n\n
In conclusion. If you haven't watched Fate/Zero, I would recommend you go watch that first. And if you have, I would recommend you not watch this pitiful excuse for a sequel.

Finished this anime a few days ago and I must say I was utterly disappointed by the series.I really liked the Fate/Zero and Fate/SN:UBW series so I though of giving this anime a shot too but I deeply regret that.
Art and Animation: 4/10
The art and animation is pretty decent but its really horrible compared to the any other fate series which right of the bat added a negative point to this anime for me. Many of you may not agree with me but to me the animation just felt like an eyesore to me.
Sound: 2/10
I didn't like the op and ed tracks but the soundtrackswhich played during the fight were so pathetic to listen to and I don't think there was a single ost from the anime which I liked.


Characters: 1/10

All the characters are so damn annoying from this anime especially our protagonist Shirou.Maybe I wouldn't have hated them so much if I haven't watched Fate/Zero and Fate/SN:UBW cause this series literally shitted over their characters especially on Saber character. 

So lets first start with the mc

Shirou Emiya - He is a person who puts other before himself and wants to  be a hero of justice. He never seems to understand his limits and jumps in to protect other even when he knows that he won't be of any help and would end up dying in vain like when he jumps in the fight between Saber and Beserker and almost ends up dying while being of zero help.
