Fate/stay night is the ultimately disappointing adaptation of the visual novel. I will try to carefully explain why.
The story is alright, the premise is very interesting, but you quickly start to notice things are off. This is the same case with the characters, they act unnatural, forced even. 
This all has to do with the fact that this anime tries to be everything that the visual novel was, which is impossible, considering the fact that the different routes made sense in their own way. If you jam them all together you get a weird, but ultimately enjoyable, mash-up of plot points and character decisions whichdon't seem to make a lot of sense.\n\n
Should you give this anime a shot? Perhaps, if you are a really big fan of the Fate universe. In any case, you should not watch this before the actual good adaptations of the different routes in the visual novel. Perhaps give this one a try if you still hunger for more Fate, just don't expect anything amazing.

Adaptations of visual novels to anime are something of a mixed bag. Sometimes, like with Clannad and Comic Party, the adaptation is a hit. Other times, it doesn't work quite so much. Fate/Stay Night falls into the former case, though there are times where the work stumbles in its execution, primarily on the animation front, though there are some narrative issues.
The animation for the series is done by Studio DEEN, and this is made during their dark period, after their high points back in the 80s with works like Angel's Egg, and before their modern redemption with Konosuba and Showa Genroku Rakugo Shinjuu. This leadsto some weird animation moments - such as clear moments where dialog scenes are taken off camera, to avoid having to animating mouth movements. Some of the action scenes also feel under-animated - including some of the shows more significant fights - like Archer's battle with Berserker. It feels like a deliberate attempt to save money on the animation budget so they can go all out in the series finale, which has an incredibly dramatic animation bump - so dramatic that it almost feels like it was animated by a completely different studio.


That said, the show's music is generally good, with a score composed by Kenji Kawai, who is known for his work on Ghost in the Shell - though the scope of the music feels, once again, limited by budget - as if he envisioned the music to be played by live musicians, only to be informed that all they could afford was a really nice synthesizer, loaded with some really good MIDI voices.


The writing is generally good. The women, particularly Saber, Rin, Taiga, and Ilya are all very interestingly and entertainingly written characters, with some great character moments. In particular, Miki Itou as Taiga livens up every scene she's in with the work, and you can almost feel her energy liven up the rest of the cast in the scenes she shares with them. That said, some of the writing around the character of Shirou stumbles. He's overly patronizing of Saber. In particular, early in the series he's unwilling to acknowledge or recognize her combat skills to a real degree - choosing to fight instead of her even when it's been demonstrated to him that she is far better with a sword than pretty much everyone. Later in the series he shows a better degree of trust, but it is still frustrating early on in the show. Later on in the series the show develops a twist that comes more or less out of nowhere, but it introduces one of the show's better antagonists, so I'll cut them some slack for that.


As far as whether you should watch the show - Ufotable has spent more time in this universe than Deen has, with prequel Fate/Zero, and the Unlimited Blade Works anime (which adapts another route through the same game). Fate/Zero sets up the rules of the Grail War, much as this does, but Fate/Zero front-loads the exposition with a massive infodump in the first, double-length episode, while this show paces the exposition better - and explains some other concepts that Fate/Zero doesn't get into (like how the magic system works).

OVERALL- ~8
Fate/Stay night was an overall solid show that I really enjoyed. Though there were flaws, they could be easily overlooked and this show could be really relished.
STORY- 8.5
The story achieved what it seemed to be striving for with a solid beginning, middle, and ending. Events were put into action in a suitable time frame and provided for a nice ride throughout.
Execution- 8
The show's story was executed without too many plotholes, much of which were with the lesser characters, and the story was done in a timely manner not spending too much or too little time on one subject. Most of the rough spots dealtmainly with the character's backstories as later written below. These rough spots muddied up parts of the plot in more minor areas but still affect part of the main plot.


Originality- 9

Battle Royale type stuff was probably already created at the time Fate/Stay Night was created in 2006, but having a battle over the Holy Grail is unique. Combined with the idea of servants, the originality scores a 9 for a truly original show.


QUALITY -  7.66

This show's quality is exceptional for something created 10 years ago and exceeds some present day work.

Art- 9

Probably the best feature of Fate/Stay Night, the animation was outstanding for a show created 10 years ago. I couldn't tell it was created in 2006 if I hadn't looked at this show into more detail. The lighting, backgrounds, and overall detail were animated superbly and the art could exceed many shows made in this early decade and maybe even some in the present time.


Sound - 8

The soundwork was also at a high level. Voice acting was conducted well enough to capture each character's likeness and personality and the music also suited well with the anime's mood. Although the OST didn't have many pieces, the pieces that were showcased fit the mood of nearly every scene.


Character- 6

Oh, the characters. While what I considered the mains (Shirou, Saber, and Rin) were developed thoroughly, many secondary and tertiary characters lacked backstory and explanation. For example, Sakura, was a key character in the later stages of the anime, but although it was explained why, it was not described with enough detail and lacked development in her character as a whole. The same thing happens with most other secondary and tertiary characters. On a personal level though, I would've liked to seen more of Archer as he is listed as a "Main" but it seems like he never got enough screen time.


ENJOYMENT - 9

I really enjoyed this anime since I saw the first episode. It was an intereting premise from the start and kept drawing my attention. This prompts me to move on to the Unlimited Blade Works and Fate/Zero aswell as Heaven's Fall this upcoming year.

Fate/Stay Night. Considered (and well should be) a staple in many action-romance genre fans like me, I had been recommended the series time and time again by my friends, so I got pretty hyped up. I think its quite a bit of a review so the TL;DR is basically the Enjoyment/Conclusion paragraph down below. 
DISCLAIMER: I have not played the visual novel so this review is purely based on the anime alone.  
Story : 8 - The story is set in modern day Japan (or what could be considered modern in 2003) and our MC, Emiya Shirou, is a typical high school kid. Thisis a shounen after all. Similar to Mirai Nikki, he lives an average life until he gets swept up in events far beyond he would ever imagine. Under attack from an unknown entity that appeared before him, Shirou summons one of his own to defend him, thus catapulting him into huge events that could decide the fate of the entire world. I actually really found this series and Mirai Nikki extremely similar in the regard that there are people playing in a death game and the prize is power on an omnipotent level. If you were the fan of the Hunger Games, this is basically that with higher stakes and more magic. I really enjoyed the story, and the second half had a lot of good plot twists but it got really slow at times for an action anime. I will explain why later. 


Art: 8 - The art is very good for a 2006 anime, and it can probably hold its own to some more recent anime as well. Obviously DEEN also did their best to make the art true to the visual novel.  It also wasn't very flashy. It gets an 8 here.


Sound: 10 - I loved the sound. The entire soundtrack fit in perfectly with the atmosphere of the series. The action sequences were also given a well deserved sort of ominous feel thanks to the soundtrack. But I really adored the OPs. Disillusion has become one of my favourite OPs of all time, seeing as to how it fit very well with the first half of the anime. Kirameku Namida wa Hoshi ni, the second OP, also fits in great with the much quicker pace of the show. I think the ED sounded beautiful.


Characters: 9 - The best part of the show, imho. I found that all the characters in the show were actually very likeable (except of course for Shinji). Without going on about too much, most of the characters had a certain depth to them. This segment gets a 9 because I really feel like some of the characters (and their relationships with each other) could have been more developed and the romance at the end felt a bit rushed. I am a true stickler for the budding romance elements of the action-romance genre so to see it rushed and the romance development skipped a bit actually hurt me, especially since this pairing is one of my favourites in all anime I've seen. 


Enjoyment/Conclusionl: 7 - I'll start with the negative. Let's face it, this anime is slow. The constant character flashbacks seriously irritated me at some points. Some of the battles were a bit draggy because of this as well. But I find that the characters, art and soundtrack seriously make up for otherwise a draggy series. Even though the romance felt a little underdeveloped for me, I still felt that it was still quite adequate. 


Really, Fate/Stay Night is a classic in my eyes. If you are an action-romance fan, I would agree that this is a staple for you. If you like a fantastic cast of characters, a good soundtrack, or maybe just a best girl argument (its Saber) than this anime is also for you. Just do not expect the romance to come too soon, it only really develops near the end. 


Overall : 8

Let me tell you straight out, I cried.
They may tell you that Fate/stay night (FSN), quality-wise, is pretty bad, and Unlimited Blade Works (UBW) is a much better version of the Holy Grail war. Must be the Organization again. Why do I say this? I am no scientist, but I can say that although UBW in terms of the quality of the plot, is indeed better -- but in terms of my personal enjoyment, and the impact it had on me, Fate/stay night, the original, is awesome nevertheless.
The characters, for one thing, are more attractive than their counterparts in UBW. Rin's face is a littletoo sharp in UBW, and more filled out in FSN. Too bad that in UBW Rin is the lead female character and Saber is in FSN, but ah well, that's precisely why I loved this so much and started rewatching it a month after the first time.


The setting is very delicately drawn. Reminsicent of the pearly shadows and lighting in Bleach, but even more emotively so. You gotta love how the characters are drawn. Just the right amount of coloring and lines to make them the right way, that perfect amount of lighting and illustration to make it all the more poignantly realistic.


Like Fate/Zero and UBW, this anime is no children's story. When characters are facing immense odds in battle, they are injured, and they shed and spout blood. I mean, if characters are wielding weapons meant to kill, then blood should be spilt. I like that. If the creators of an anime are the purveyors of a certain segment of a group of characters' lives, then it should be realistic, because although that world may have different rules than ours, it's still a world of humans, and the premise is for the most part the same. So when characters fight characters and the worst that happens is bruises and unconsciousness (I'm talking to you, Fairy Tail), it irks me, because it doesn't make sense how swords can not spill blood. The fight scenes are awesome, of course, as they were for Fate/Zero and UBW.


The openings and endings of FSN are perfect in that they portray the emotional and motivational context of the characters and plot. The main ending, the soothing lullaby with Saber in the grassy field, is perfect. The openings with the Servants and Masters. The final ending, which brought tears to my eyes upon seeing it. The soundtrack, when listening to it in my YouTube playlist (A Scintillating Rain, the one with 900+ videos), is one of the most enjoyable to listen to. It's not particularly awesome or anything, but for each song in the OST I can almost always link it to a certain event in the anime. Very playful and emotive OST.


CHARACTER. Now this is the real good stuff. Shirou Emiya -- if you want to see an epitome of chivalry, then watch FSN. He helps others always, and values the lives of others over his own. He is weak, but perseveres in the face of strong adversaries. Saber -- I gotta say, of all the female anime characters I've seen, she is one of the hottest. Being straight out honest here. The way her eyes suck you in like frozen pools... I say frozen for a reason, she is a true Servant in that she pursues her goal, her raison d'etre for being alive again in this world. Archer, and his disdain for Shirou's ideals... Why is he so aloof? Lancer, Caster, Assassin, Rider, Berserker. Seven Servants, seven Masters. There is a reason why I loved this so much. A reason so utterly beautiful that I can't bring myself to say it, because you gotta see this for yourself.... Just watch it, okay?


"If you cannot defeat your enemy with the weapon you do have, then imagine one with which you could."


one word to describe this anime: heart-wrenching

This anime was one of the few that really kick-started my love for anime in general. Though many see it as a half-arsed adaptation of Type-Moon's Visual Novel 'Fate/Stay Night' following the shows amazing prequel Fate/Zero and 2014-2015 brilliant adaptation Fate/Stay Night Unlimited Blade/Budget Works which makes me rather upset. 
Story: The story is set around the basis is that there is this event called the Holy Grail War where servants or heroes of the past, present and future come together to fight for their masters (usually who are Mages) that summoned them to the current timeline to fight for possession of an object knownas the Holy Grail which is said to grant any wish proposed to it. The servants and masters fight in the style of a battle royale. The grail has appeared for the fifth time, and now the Grail War takes place in Fuyuki City, Japan with our main hero and Heroine being Shirou Emiya and Saber. Whilst the overall premise of the story is good and fresh...it’s not really a battle royal since every few episodes a new servant/master pair appear and challenge our main heroes Shirou Emiya and his servant Saber (Atoria/Arthur Pendragon) through various means that are either confusing or predictable. They are the main characters so of course they should always be the victor, plot armour 101 ladies and gentleman! Magic was also not clearly explained in this story as it spent way too much time explaining what exactly the Holy Grail War is and how it works (exposition in this story gets up to extreme levels of OMG WHOULD YOU GET ON WITH IT ALREADY!). But! This show is actually really well paced and is not afraid to show some dark imagery or tear-jerking moments as the show carries on through its 24 episode run time. The fight scenes were also well connected not random like some other anime and also connected aspects of humour or unexpected sadness. \n
Animation: The animation was done by studio deen in 2006, so no it does not live up to the animation of today but for its time the animation was great especially in the fight scenes. However, the one thing that we all can agree on that was complete dog shit animation was that CGI dragon (never do that again).\n
Sound: whilst the music for the show is basically remixes of the visual novels music I found myself quite found of it especially of the main characters titular theme ‘Emiya’ which has since been redone so many times. But the shows two openings and endings were rather unmemorable and quite skippable after a few times of watching them.\n
Character: When first watching this anime I fell in love with most of these characters instantly, I loved their mannerisms, their appearances, their actions and how they were involved in the story and to some extent I still do. Rin is probably still one of my favorite characters in any anime which extended to the 2014-2015 anime and Archer and Saber are still awesome but my favorite character is Gilgamesh (who is also my fav male anime character of all time). Yeah he is incredibly overpowered and was introduced very late in the story and he acts like such an asshole but I...Love...IT! His cocky attitude makes him the perfect counter to the normal calm Saber which is especially shown in the final battle but honestly to understand why he is so amazing. But like so many others I really disliked Shirou...I found his 'I want to save everyone' attitude stupid and that one stupid FAIL translated dialogue "People die when they are killed" made me wish someone would just stab him and say "Yes Shirou. Yes they do". However I did like his progression from somewhat of a lackluster mage to semi-competent along with his relationship with Saber and Rin (so their is something positive about that guy). \n
Enjoyment: You would enjoy this the most if you have not watched Fate/Zero or Unlimited Blade Works 2014-2015 since the animation is nothing compared to what Ufotable has done with it and you don’t have any major spoilers already given to you (especially with Fate/Zero). It is also in my opinion a very well done starting anime for any people just getting into anime as it incorporates many different tropes that are typical in anime. \n
Overall: Do I think Fate/Stay Night is shit? No. Do I think Fate/Stay Night is amazing? No. I think that for the first adaption of the now infamous Fate Series that it was well done and enjoyable to sit through (despite Shirou’s immense stupidity and that damn CGI dragon). It the best entrance into the series along with a good gateway anime. The animation is still good and the music is great. Whilst some parts are dumb others can make you cry out in despair at the reality that these characters are living in. along with a satisfying conclusion…Fate/Stay Night is one anime that should be viewed and not judged for its successful follow ups. If your looking for an anime to get attached to then this anime was fated to be viewed by you.\n
P.S. Forgive me that pun was awful

Fate/Stay night was interesting indeed. Although at times I thought it was moving a little too slow, it remained interesting enough for me to continue watching it. This focuses a lot on Sabre, who is an epic hero. It focuses on her past and the relationship between her and the main protagonist. One thing I must say about this series is that the soundtrack is horrible. I swear I found it annoying. Of course many would say not to watch this and watched the new alternative story better since the art is excellent and this is crap compared to it. While I won't disagree, ifyou decide to go into the Fate franchise, I recommend watching this before the UNLIMITED BLADEWORKS, and not the other way around. This will give you a nice taste of what it's all about then when you watch UNLIMITED BLADEWORKS, you will get the entire entree. If you feel like you don't like it from the start, then just drop it and watch the alternative.\n\n
I personally like the use of Epic Heroes in this anime because it utilizes hero from stories of the past and incorporates their legends. If you're into stuff like King Arthur, Hercules and others, watch this.

I watched this after finishing the more mature Fate Zero which I had trouble getting into but ended up loving at the end because it grew so epic. This anime was released before Fate Zero but the story is set after it,  I have to stress that if I had not watched Fate Zero before, I probably wouldn't have finished Stay Night. 
This is basically a Shounen harem version of Zero, where instead of focusing on many characters, the focus here is all on one. The main character gets surrounded by females to a point where it just gets ridiculous and it's hard totake seriously. His relationship with his "servant" also is really hard to take seriously, especially if you consider that his servant was originally male. Nevermind why the hell it's a female here, I have no idea why after two shows featuring him/her. 


For a story about a War between epic heroes, they are really underused which is a crying shame. They have a finishing move called a Noble Phantasm but we barely get to see them and half of them don't even use theirs.


While I kept watching to see what would happen next in the second half of the series which had great pacing, I was extremely let down by the last few episodes and the ending, even getting pissed off. The only reason I kept at it is because of having seen Fate Zero first, so I would recommend staying away from this if you haven't seen or didn't like Fate Zero. That being said, I am checking out the other Fate adaptations soon, just because Zero was so enjoyable.

Honestly I wondered why Fate/Stay Night had a 7.95 as an overall rating, after watching the first 13 episode I loved it, it had alot of action and the characters really seemed to change accordingly. Though after finishing the series I understand why people might give this anime a low rating.
*********************Spoiler Alert***************************
Well after seeing the ending episodes I started to wonder is Shirou going to get to stay with Saber or is Saber going back in her own time. Well I wanted them to stay together in the modern world,but sadly no she ended up leaving and honestly.. When that happen I basically just died...Well not literally, but hey I really wanted them to stay together I felt like the 24 episodes I spent watching were all for nothing.Maybe it's just me who wants an ending where it goes all happy n stuff I don't know. Well anyways im going to watch Fate Zero and see how that turns out hopefully Saber and Shirou gets back together even though I Doubt it because it's a prequel but hey I can hope can't I? :P

Fate/stay night is a great anime on its own, although it's not as thrilling as Fate/zero.
Unlike Fate/zero you can't feel connected to all the servants, not all their stories are told and some remain unknown heroes, it might be intentionally like this, but personally i miss this connection.
Many loose ends from Fate/zero are being resolved here.
If you liked the battles and action in Fate/zero and it's the only reason you are going to watch Fate/stay night, than don't bother watching, although there are battles in it, it's definitely not the reason to watch this anime.
I really liked this but if it has to be comparedto its prequel than it is definitely going to lose.

First review on MAL!
Well, i had give up Fate/Stay Night a long time ago at episode 12... I re-watched it with TV-Reprodution to remind the plot and the characters. Fate was my very first Type-Moon anime, and I think it really conveys the to "Type-mooned" feelings : lot of talking about the characters, about mysteries and, First Time I watched it, I was really, really bored about that. But I think with Fate, you really have to enter in the universe to appreciate it, no words are useless, and you will be get by the anime at one time! Personnaly, I can't deny it: iget a bit bored by the 12 first episodes, but the suit is sure sort of epic and awesome... When I think about this show now, I realize that he was godd from the beginning to the end.



--------


Now, let's concentrate on story.

The plot is quite ejoyable: 7 master summon each 7 servants who will fight with them into the Grall War. The winning team will own the Holy Grall whitch can fullfil all your wishes Here, the story concentrates on Emiya Shirô, a normal boy who had weak magic powers. One day, the servant Saber appears in his warehouse. Emiya will face the 6 others servants and masters, dealing with his and Saber's past, and her motivations to get the Holy Grall.

I have nothing more to say about the story, I give the maximum score, because, the story is very well exploited, and is sort of complex, despite the quite simple orignal plot.


For the art, I have nothing to say either. I love the style of Type-Moon graphisms, and it fits so well with Fate/SN. I get a bit bored by some talking scenes when the characters do not move so much, but it's compensed by the beautiful animations of fight scenes


Next step is music. The OST composed by Kenji Kawaii is just awesome. When I watch an anime, the OST is one of the first things I pay a particular attention too. The music convey us the feelings of great medieval battles, and always go well with the animation. To talk quickly about the OPs/EDs, well I am not a big fan of Tanaika Sachi, but "Disillusion" still a nice song.


For characters, well, I think I already have talked a bit about it. Every characters has his own personnality, even Emiya hasn't a too cliched character for a hero. The servants are all more awesome than the others, if I have to pick a favorite, it would be Assasin or Lancer... The secondary characters like Tohsaka are also good. Nothing more to say about this category, every one will find his own favorite.


Finally, this anime was very enjoyable. The ending didn't disapoint me at all (maybe beacause I know I would watch Fate/zero just after), I think I'll maybe re-watch in when I will have time. In the end, I think Fate/Stay Night, is one of the anime you must try to watch, I know everyone is not fan of the Type-Moon way of dealing with story.  Accorded to my feelings, I think Fate is not the best Type-Moon anime to begin with. To familiarise with the atmosphere of these animes, I'll advise you too watch Kara No Kyoukai or Tsukihime first. If you are already a T-M fan and if you didn't watch F/SN (whitch would be surprising), just go and watch it.

I must admit that when I first started watching this series, its atmosphere came off a little bit on the boring side for me. And in general, there are a few scenes throughout the episodes that gave off the same type of vibe (for example, I thought a handful of the fights were fairly predictable with no real major twists). The characters also seem typical, but are still very good; they're well developed and come off as pretty cool people. Especially Rin Tohsaka.
The only other problem I had with Fate/Stay Night is the lack of explanation it provided. There are a few relationships between charactersthat are not clearly explained, some of their pasts are never even mentioned or they are just given in very brief flashbacks if at all. I'm not saying an entire episode (or even more) needs to be devoted solely on a flashback of someone's life in order to understand them better, but a little more elaboration certainly would have helped. 


I loved the animation, especially the way that the character designs looked. Saber's in particular I thought looked really cool, as well as the way that Eleanor and Berserker stood out beside each other (creepy combo much!) -- Every bit of the art was just brilliant. 


All in all, and this is taking into account that the anime itself was on a low budget, I thought this was a very good show. There are little things here and there that bothered me about it but as a whole I really did enjoy it and definitely plan to watch its sequel. I score it at an 8/10

I have played the VN game for hours, like it kept me going on and going on and go to bed at 6 am xD The story is incredibly good. I'm in love with it ! :D
Though, I found the anime adaptation not as interesting as the game is. At first, I was amazed to see animated fights, for they are not really in the VN. But then, I found the whole thing a bit boring.... Maybe cause I already played the game and the story is going much and much further... Moreover, Shirou's animation is lousy to me. It made me think of aplaymobil. It was the only thing very disapointing.


Yet, the sounds are great and I love the remade original theme musics. It's a pleasure to listen to new versions of the songs you enjoyed listening while playing the game. The voices are quite accurate to me, and I'm not disapointed on that !


To conclude, I think this is a quite good adaptation, aiming the essentials of the VN, that must be very enjoying for anyone who hasn't played the game first ! :)

I don't hate this anime, and I can see why some people would probably enjoy this. 
The story had some plot holes, but other than that it's ok.
 The art is clean, but also on the average side with some nice effects.
 The sound is where it shines,not with the english dub voice acting . . . but with the music.
 The characters varied from good to dreadful. The main protagonist, Shirou, is particularly is retarded, but his servant Saber is ok.
As far as enjoyment went, I felt like every episode was just one fight after another. And what really threw my enjoyment of theseries out the window was the sketchy hentai-sex type scenes thrown into the middle of it. Made it awkward to watch with my wife.\n\n
Pretty mediocre anime by my taste, but seriously, listen to the music and enjoy it.

Finished watching fate/stay night yesterday, the anime has a great ending and is well worth watching through the 24 episodes just to get to it. However, it is a bit slow it delivering that ending and at some points you do want it to hurry up a bit. There is quite a lot of repetitive dialog which does get annoying, but its hard to find anything without repetitive dialog. These problems however are very small compared to the impact that the show delivers. Overall it is well worth watching and no doubt re-watching. Unmissable!

SUMMARY: IT WAS A WASTE OF POTENTIAL
...WOW... I believe I, like many others,  may have had too high of expectations.. So I want to tell all of you people who are considering watching this... It is not an AMAZING anime... Is it good enough to finish? yes.... Did it sometimes make me wonder what was going to happen next? Yes... HOWEVER: Does it have annoying characters and easily forseen plot twists? YES
OK... more in depth: 
STORY- GREAT! Got me hooked in seconds... sounded interesting, pretty unique, and had a lot of ways it could have gone. However, this amazing amount of potential was wastedwith lack of developement of characters and a pretty boring and uninspired take on the storyline.


ART: ok... not horrible, nothing  was beyond amazing, not like some of the prequels and such that have come out for this anime, but still nothing absolutely terrible either. 


SOUND: um... ok again... since I did not notice it it must not have been fantastic or horrible....


CHARACTERS: UGGGGGGGGGGGGH!!!! SUCH A WASTE! They could have done sooo much more with them... instead they have the main male lead as one of the most annoying characters of all time with some crazy justice obsession. The multiple strong girl characters would have been much more entertaining and likeable if they did not become part of a sort of harem for the pathetic male lead. And the side characters, who were decently entertaining, were not given enough screen time and their stories were not gone into enough.... granted, some stories are well known (i won't give spoilers but some of these people are legends) but still, for the viewer that has not read greek literature or medival literature for a while, it would have been nice if the writer would have done a memory refresher so that we could relate to them more and feel more pain when they died or made a sacrifice.      Many of the more main chracters ran into this problem as well... not enough past developement... (I am not refering to the main two characters...)


SUMMARY: AT TOP

Where can I begin when talking about Fate/Stay Night? For starters, it is the adaptation of the visual novel of the same name, and follows the Fate arc of said visual novel. I myself read the visual novel before watching the anime. As far as visual novels go, it had it's issues, but I felt it was well done overall, if a bit drawn out at times. But this is a review for the anime. To begin with, it felt as if it was trying to fit in as much as possible in as little time as it could, which is to be expected Isuppose, but as a result, a large portion of characterization was lost. In the visual novel, you get to hear and understand to an extend Shirou's thought process. You don't get that in the anime, so he seems really shallow and a pretty big weenie. And while he is a weenie in the Fate route of the visual novel, he is more of one in the anime. I don't really have much else to say about the anime other than that it wasn't a very good adaptation. If you are considering watching it, I would strongly recommend that you read the Fate/Stay Night visual novel instead. I think you would find it much more enjoyable.

Just so you know I first watched Fate/Zero and then Fate/Stay Night.After watching FZ,FSN seemed a little bit more childish.A lot of the masters were teenagers and just the whole atmosphere is not as tense as in FZ.Another difference is that we see a little bit more feminine side of Saber which I kinda liked.Shirou gets dragged into the war without realising it with Saber as his servant (summoned for the second time since the last war) Tohsaka Rin who is now grown up also is a master (continuing it for her father) Rin is the character that totally stole me this time.My girl crushfor Saber was split into Rin :D She got to show her good personality even sacrificing her servant Archer who also gained my liking after some time.Besides from Rin we also get to see her sister Sakura who is also grown up now (as a part of the Matou family) She has a role of helping Shirou in the kitchen.She has a whole different role in the "heaven's feel" route of the game which I haven't played so I cannot say much about that.\n
I like how there's some relationship going on between Shirou and Saber although I kind of like Shirou x Rin,which is more in the movie version "Unlimited Blade Works".Anyway...another important character is Illyasviel (Kiritsugu and Irisviel's daughter) who seems to also be in the war having Berserker as a servant.I'm not gonna give out any spoilers so if you want to know how it all ends go watch it for yourself! FSN is a favorite of mine!

I really like this series. It is a little older so the animation and sound isn't what we're now used to, but the story and characters are fun to watch. There's a bit of mystery surrounding the main character, and he has a great sense of right and wrong. The relationships he builds with Rin and Sakura (a couple of girls that are in fact supposed to be his competition but are his friends) are what set him apart from the rest of his competition, and it's these relationships that help him throughout the series. Even though he's a "mage" he's not all powerful andhe doesn't know a lot of magic. He himself is quite heroic, and he stays true to his character throughout the story.


I like that his summoned hero trains him to be a part of the battles so he can protect himself. He doesn't want to sit by and watch someone get hurt for him which is quite admirable. It's a completely different feel than it's prequel Fate/Zero. There is a lot of love in this story, and when you're battling for the holy grail, it's good to have a little hope. Pieces of the storys mysteries are unraveled throughout, and it's intelligently done. There's good character development, and they squeeze a lot of emotion into this story.


This is a must watch, but do watch this before the prequel (Fate/Zero), as it will eliminate a few holes in that story.

This series poses a conumdrum. Everything about this anime is very good, but I hated it.
My reasons being the story. It's a very good story, but I felt that it detracted from the original visual novel, and I also felt that it should have focused solely on the Fate arc, and nothing else.
I feel that the Tsukehime adaptation suffered the same problem. Maybe it's just fate that anime versions shouldn't be made from TypeMoon games.

Okay, so I played/read the source Material, and I also went in knowing it couldn't be a 1-1 Re-creation of the Visual Novel, but this Anime right off the bat disappointed me.
Several characters are so Out of character it annoys me. Archer, for example, just...
Like dude, you're being a li'l bitch in the anime, whereas in the VN (And later UFOtable Adaptation of UBW) You're an asshole with a purpose.
Shirou was never a very compelling character to begin with but he even manages to fall short of that in this version.
Tohsaka is probably most accurate so I won't really shit on her.
Idunno, It feels likethe writers just read the Cliff notes and tried to make an Anime based on that alone

This is one of my first reviews here. I normally review anime on Netflix and Crunchyroll and use their 5 star like or dislike system. I prefer that over the 10 point scale.
Anyway, apparently the Fate series was first a bunch of visual novels that they decided to make into an anime series in 2006 called Fate/Stay Night. A few years later they released another series called Fate/Zero.
Fate/Zero in terms of the anime, is the prequel to Fate/Stay Night. A lot of people have said that it's better to watch Stay Night first before watching Zero. I completely disagree with that.
Fate/Zero is good starting pointfor any interested in the series. It goes in depth as to what the holy grail wars are all about, and sets up the events and story of Stay Night.\n\n
While I agree that Stay Night was not as good as Fate/Zero I still really enjoyed it. A lot of the things that were mentioned or briefly covered in Stay Night occured in Zero. You'll miss out on a lot of things if you decide to take the advice of the Visual Novels fans and choose the wrong one to watch first.

When I first watched this show, it was a somewhat confusing but extremely entertaining piece of work. Now that I have a lot more Ufotable under my belt, it still holds as a must watch for anyone interested in the Fate universe, especially for those who like Saber.
I've heard quite a bit about this show before watching it and I must say, it lived up to my expectations. FSN is a dark thriller-action with elements of magic and a hint of romance. Overall, the show was a blast to watch and maintained a very high bar of quality throughout. Don't be surprised if you findyourself forgetting the time and continuously watching marathon style.


Animation:

First, I'll point out that the characters are well drawn. Unlike many other shows, the characters actually look relatively (not necessarily behave) mature rather than just cute. Granted, now with hindsight everything here is way childish compared to Fate/Zero. In addition, there are very many battles here in which effects are heavily used in a very effective fashion. Note that there is a considerable amount of blood. And yes there is indeed a character named Rin Tousaka who is just begging to be watched. That said, those who really like Tousaka should check out the newer Unlimited Blade Works retelling.


Sound:

The voice acting was well done, obviously I'm going to point out Kana Ueda for doing an awesome job as Rin- such a prime combination of cuteness and bite.


The music in general is superb. The first OP in particular is extremely memorable and fitting, with a hint of mystery. Kenji Kawai also did an absolutely brilliant job on the BGM, giving the show a very unique and atmosphere-rich feel.


Story:

I'll start with the negatives since there aren't very many. Don't expect heroes to coincide with what you know the heroes to be. They are only loosely based on historic figures and the anime takes its liberty to modify what it sees necessary (King Arthur = female??). Also, there are many intricacies such as the real identity of Archer that you may not get at first.


As for the actual plot sequence, it is superbly done. The viewer is kept waiting to find out who is Shiro's next opponent and then, once the plot plays out, rewards the watcher lavishly. Watching the uphill battle between the odd pair of Shiro and Saber (the weakest, pseudo-magician and the strongest servant) and the other masters was very intense. Throw in another magician (Rin) and her Archer servant and you have one awesome action adventure.


As an aside, there is also the question of a romantic development between Shiro and Sakura/Rin/Saber.


Character:

Shiro is a dynamic character. From the beginning, he seeks the idyllic dream of being a champion of justice. His only passion is to help and protect others, at whatever cost to himself. Others find this do-goody personality very annoying since he seems completely incorruptible. However, by the end, he is fighting for a completely different reason. Shiro and Saber begin as a master/servant relationship but after a few battles, it is apparent their relationship develops into something further than just that. I found this development to be very well executed; there's quite a bit of foreshadow if you look for it.


There's also Rin! She seems to be an amazingly talented magician yet it is obviously clear that she has some feelings for Shiro (and a perfect example of what tsundere should be). Overall, the development of the characters is done extremely well. You'll realize that even the villains will have some good points.


Value:

This show is not too long, and is very action-packed and plot-driven. It might start out a little slow but the overall show is very fast paced and will keep you on your toes. I re-watched it right after finishing to pick up on more subtleties. Definitely a classic, and a reference point by which to judge other action shows.
